awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a fluorescence microscope to grow research and training at St. Catherine University
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to St. Catherine University, a primarily undergraduate institution, to acquire a Leica DM6B fluorescence microscope. This microscope will expand the research capacity of biology faculty at the university and will engage students from the university's College for Women in research training in the biological sciences. St. Catherine has among the most ethnically and economically diverse population of students enrolled in Minnesota's four-year public and private colleges. The fluorescence microscope will help prepare women undergraduates of all backgrounds to succeed in graduate school and scientific careers by providing access to and training in modern microscopy, imaging techniques and image analysis. The expanded research capacity made possible by the microscope will also contribute to efforts to recruit excellent and diverse faculty while aiding current faculty to conduct research. Access to this instrumentation will stimulate new collaborations among faculty within the university's Biology Department, between biology faculty and those in broader STEM disciplines, and with existing research collaborators at other universities.

The deconvolution DIC fluorescence microscope will expand research programs spanning the areas of ecology, developmental biology, genetics, cell and molecular biology, and phylogenetics for four biology faculty. A project investigating how nitrogen and phosphorus shape and control the structure and function of cyanobacterial and algal assemblages will contribute to the ability to better predict changes to freshwater ecosystems in response to environmental stressors. The exploration of the development of dimorphic traits in Caenorhabditis elegans will provide insights on the role Hox genes in neuronal development. The characterization of the temporal or spatial subfunctionalization of ammonium transporters in the model liverwort Marchantia polymorpha will elucidate the evolutionary consequences of gene transfer between domains of living organisms. Selective staining of heterochromatin with fluorescent probes will allow detection of differences in chromatin structure that might impact the physiology, gene expression, and ecobiology of diploid compared to polyploid populations of the non-model invertebrate, Lumbriculus. Not only will this microscope meet the current needs of the biology department, it will also allow for programmatic expansion in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of our project was to acquire a modern fluorescence microscope to expand the research capacity of our biology faculty and strengthen our engagement of our diverse undergraduate community in rigorous research training in the biological sciences at St. Catherine University. Acquisition of this microscope was key to recruiting and supporting the research of two new faculty members and allowed us to accomplish research objectives in a wide variety of biological disciplines:  


Aquatic and community ecology: Increasingly the health of our freshwaters is threatened by climatic and human-derived pressures such as invasive species and eutrophication that alter watershed attributes to fundamentally change the species composition and abundance of cyanobacteria and algae toward nuisance and harmful taxa.This project identified how temperature and nutrients can act and interact to shift biofilm structure and species composition between more nutritious diatoms and less nutritious, and potentially toxic cyanobacteria. 


Genetics and development: This project addressed a fundamental question in developmental neurobiology: How is regional neuron identity regulated? Results from genetic analysis and protein interaction assays support a model in which the C. elegans Hox proteins, LIN-39 and MAB-5, can regulate regional neuron identity by acting cooperatively to activate and individually to activate or repress neuronal gene expression.  These results highlight the continued relevance of the genetic approach to understanding patterning and specification in development.


Phylogenetics and evolutionary biology: This project explored the fundamental evolutionary question of how novel traits evolve at the molecular level, taking as a case study an ancient horizontal gene transfer event that introduced a novel ammonium transporter into the genomes of land plants. Acquisition of the xenolog appears to have precipitated functional changes in the native transporter (AMTs). Tracing the timing of functional changes relative to the horizontal gene transfer (HGT) event sheds light on the consequences of HGT on gene and genome evolution. 


Molecular biology: A first step in exploring the impact of heterochromatin on gene expression in Lumbriculus is determining the levels of heterochromatin in diploid compared to polyploid populations. Analysis of stained chromosome spreads revealed cytogenetic differences between diploid and polyploid populations of Lumbriculus. Differences in localization of heterochromatin have been associated with speciation events, can be used to identify cryptic species, and have value in phylogenetic analysis of closely related species. The cytogenetic data obtained using the fluorescence microscope will provide additional data through which to resolve the taxonomic classification of these organisms. This is important because interpretation and comparison of toxicological results could be affected by genetic variation in the populations of Lumbriculus being used for basic molecular studies and as environmental indicator organisms.


To engage the undergraduate community in rigorous research training, student-faculty research collaborations and course-based research projects provided opportunities for students to learn different microscopy techniques like DIC, phase contrast, or fluorescence. Students then applied the appropriate techniques in their projects to collect data. Twelve students received more extensive training through student-faculty collaborative research experiences. Over 75 students in four laboratory courses learned microscopy techniques and gathered data for a course-based research project or laboratory experiences. In addition, more than 150 students in more than a dozen laboratory classes engaged in microscopy demonstrations that highlighted many different microscopy techniques like fluorescence, DIC, and phase, as well as, reinforced biological concepts like cell division, transformation, cellular structures, and diversity.
